danfulea.phys.egs

Class EGS4Core

  • java.lang.Object
    • danfulea.phys.egs.EGS4Core

  • public class EGS4Core
extends java.lang.Object
    Core class for Monte Carlo simulation of photon-electorn transport. All physics behind particle interaction with matter are sampled here. Based on EGS4/EGSnrc routines developed by SLAC(Stanford Linear Accelerator Center)/NRC (National Research Council of Canada).
    Author:
    Dan Fulea, 02 OCT. 2005

    • Method Detail

      • SHOWER

        public static void SHOWER(int IQI,
                          double EI,
                          double XI,
                          double YI,
                          double ZI,
                          double UI,
                          double VI,
                          double WI,
                          int IRI,
                          double WTI)
        Starts the "shower", the coupled photon-electron simulation.
        Parameters:
        IQI - the incident particle charge
        EI - the incident particle energy (total, i.e. kinetic + restMass if electrons)
        XI - the incident particle X coordinate
        YI - the incident particle Y coordinate
        ZI - the incident particle Z coordinate
        UI - the incident particle U directional cosine
        VI - the incident particle V directional cosine
        WI - the incident particle W directional cosine
        IRI - the incident particle region index
        WTI - the incident particle weight

      • ELECTR

        protected static void ELECTR()
        Called by SHOWER. Handles electron interaction with matter.

      • BREMS

        protected static void BREMS()
        Called by ELECTR. Samples bremsstrahlung energy using Coulomb corrected Bethe-Heitler above 50 MeV and Bethe-Heitler below 50 MeV.
        if ibr_nist = 0, the NIST bremsstrahlung cross section data base (prepared in a form of an alias table for rapid sampling) is used.
        To use bremsstrahlung splitting, set nbr_split to the desired number greater than 1 (1 is the default). Be aware that event-by-event energy conservation is NOT guaranteed, so don't use for calculations where this is important (e.g. calculation of detector response functions). The result will be nbr_split photons, all with the weight wt(npold)/nbr_split, and an electron with the original weight and energy given by the incident energy - energy of last photon.

      • MOLLER

        protected static void MOLLER()
        Called by ELECTR. DISCRETE MOLLER SCATTERING HAS BEEN ARBITRARILY DEFINED AND CALCULATED TO MEAN MOLLER SCATTERINGS WHICH IMPART TO THE SECONDARY ELECTRON SUFFICIENT ENERGY THAT IT BE TRANSPORTED DISCRETELY. THE THRESHOLD TO TRANSPORT AN ELECTRON DISCRETELY IS A TOTAL ENERGY OF AE OR A KINETIC ENERGY OF TE=AE-RM. SINCE THE KINETIC ENERGY TRANSFER IS ALWAYS, BY DEFINITION, LESS THAN HALF OF THE INCIDENT KINETIC ENERGY, THIS IMPLIES THAT THE INCIDENT ENERGY, EIE, MUST BE LARGER THAN THMOLL=TE*2+RM. THE REST OF THE COLLISION CONTRIBUTION IS SUBTRACTED CONTINUOUSLY FROM THE ELECTRON AS IONIZATION LOSS DURING TRANSPORT.

      • eii_sample

        protected static void eii_sample(int ish,
                                 int iZ,
                                 double Uj)
        Called by MOLLER. Sample EII (Electron Impact Ionization).
        Parameters:
        ish - ish
        iZ - iZ
        Uj - Uj

      • BHABHA

        protected static void BHABHA()
        Called by ELECTR. DISCRETE BHABHA SCATTERING HAS BEEN ARBITRARILY DEFINED AND CALCULATED TO MEAN BHABHA SCATTERINGS WHICH IMPART TO THE SECONDARY ELECTRON SUFFICIENT ENERGY THAT IT BE TRANSPORTED DISCRETELY, I.E. E=AE OR T=TE. IT IS NOT GUARANTEED THAT THE FINAL POSITRON WILL HAVE THIS MUCH ENERGY HOWEVER. THE EXACT BHABHA DIFFERENTIAL CROSS SECTION IS USED.

      • ANNIH

        protected static void ANNIH()
        Called by ELECTR. Handle two gamma from electron-positron anihhilation. If the user requests radiative splitting (via nbr_split greater than 1), this routine produces 2*nbr_split annihilation photons at once, each carying the fraction 1/nbr_split of the weight of the incident positron.

      • msdist_pII

        protected static void msdist_pII(double e0,
                                 double eloss,
                                 double tustep,
                                 double rhof,
                                 int medium,
                                 int qel,
                                 boolean spin_effects,
                                 double u0,
                                 double v0,
                                 double w0,
                                 double x0,
                                 double y0,
                                 double z0)
        Called by ELECTR. This subroutine models multiple elastic scattering and spatial deflections for a given path-length tustep.
        Parameters:
        e0 - e0, electron kinetic energy at the beginning of step
        eloss - eloss, energy loss for this step
        tustep - tustep, total pathlength of the step
        rhof - rhof, density scaling template (as in EGS4)
        medium - medium, medium number
        qel - qel, qel =0 for e-, =1 for e+, needed for spin effects
        spin_effects - spin_effects
        u0 - u0, x-direction cosine before scattering
        v0 - v0, y-direction cosine before scattering
        w0 - w0, z-direction cosine before scattering
        x0 - x0, initial x-position
        y0 - y0, initial y-position
        z0 - z0, initial z-position

      • msdist_pI

        protected static void msdist_pI(double e0,
                                double eloss,
                                double tustep,
                                double rhof,
                                int medium,
                                int qel,
                                boolean spin_effects,
                                double u0,
                                double v0,
                                double w0,
                                double x0,
                                double y0,
                                double z0)
        Called by ELECTR. This subroutine models multiple elastic scattering and spatial deflections for a given path-length tustep resampling (old) PRESTA-I behaviour.
        Parameters:
        e0 - e0, electron kinetic energy at the beginning of step
        eloss - eloss, energy loss for this step
        tustep - tustep, total pathlength of the step
        rhof - rhof, density scaling template (as in EGS4)
        medium - medium, medium number
        qel - qel, qel =0 for e-, =1 for e+, needed for spin effects
        spin_effects - spin_effects
        u0 - u0, x-direction cosine before scattering
        v0 - v0, y-direction cosine before scattering
        w0 - w0, z-direction cosine before scattering
        x0 - x0, initial x-position
        y0 - y0, initial y-position
        z0 - z0, initial z-position

      • mscat

        protected static void mscat(double lambda,
                            double chia2,
                            double q1,
                            double elke,
                            double beta2,
                            int qel,
                            int medium,
                            boolean spin_effects)
        Internally used by ELECTR, msdist_pII and msdist_pI. Subroutine to sample multiple electron scattering angles from the exact distribution resulting from elastic scattering described by the screened Rutherford cross section (spin_effects=false) or by the screened Rutherford cross times Mott correction (spin_effects=true).
        Parameters:
        lambda - lambda
        chia2 - chia2
        q1 - q1
        elke - elke
        beta2 - beta2
        qel - qe1
        medium - medium
        spin_effects - spin_effects

        protected static void sscat(double chia2,
                            double elke,
                            double beta2,
                            int qel,
                            int medium,
                            boolean spin_effects)
        Called by ELECTR. Sample the single elastic scattering.
        Parameters:
        chia2 - chia2
        elke - elke
        beta2 - beta2
        qel - qe1
        medium - medium
        spin_effects - spin_effects

      • spin_rejection

        protected static double spin_rejection(int qel,
                                       int medium,
                                       double elke,
                                       double beta2,
                                       double q1,
                                       double cost,
                                       boolean is_single)
        Used internally in mscat and sscat. Determines the rejection function due to spin effects.
        Parameters:
        qel - charge qel (=0 for e-, =1 for e+)
        medium - medium
        elke - log(energy)
        beta2 - beta2
        q1 - first MS moment
        cost - cos(theta)
        is_single - is_single
        Returns:
        the result

      • PHOTON

        protected static void PHOTON()
        Called by SHOWER. Handles photon interaction with matter.

      • PAIR

        protected static void PAIR()
        Called by PHOTON. For a photon energy below 2.1 MeV, the energies of the pair particles are uniformly distributed in the allowed range via the default replacement for SELECT-LOW-ENERGY-PAIR-PRODICTION; For a photon energy between 2.1 and 50 MeV the Bethe-Heitler cross section is employed, above 50 MeV the Coulomb-corrected Bethe-Heitler is used.

      • COMPT

        protected static void COMPT()
        Called by PHOTON. Subroutine for sampling incoherent (Compton) scattering. If the flag ibcmp(region) is zero, Klein-Nishina is used. Otherwise scattering is modelled in the impuls approximation (see R.Ribberfors and K.F.Berggren, Phys.Rev.A26 (1982) 3325). As the total cross section from PEGS4 is not modified (and thus calculated using Klein-Nishina), all rejections leed to an unscattered photon and a zero energy electron. If a K,L1,L2,L3,M or N vacancy is created, the subsequent atomic relaxation is treated in RELAX. This has as a consequence that more than one particle can be created as a result of an incoherent scattering.

      • PHOTO

        protected static void PHOTO()
        Called by PHOTON. Sample the photoelectric effect. The emission of Fluorescent X-rays, Auger, Coster-Kronig electrons are treated in RELAX.

      • RELAX

        protected static void RELAX(double energy,
                            int n,
                            int iZ)
        Called by eii_sample, COMPT, PHOTO. Sample atomic relaxation. Subroutine to fill a vacancy in shell n, element iZ by emitting fluorescent X-rays, Auger and Coster-Kronig electrons. Transitions between K,L1,L2,L3,average M,average N are taken into account. Particles with energies above the transport cut-offs (ECUT and PCUT) are placed on the stack, energy of sub-threshold particles is stored in EDEP. In this version a global cut-off of 1 keV applies, i.e. if ECUT-RM or PCUT is below 1 keV, binding energies below 1 keV will still be absorbed locally (due to lack of data).
        Parameters:
        energy - energy
        n - n
        iZ - iZ

      • UPHI

        protected static void UPHI(int IENTRY,
                           int LVL)
        Internally used. UPHI STANDS FOR 'UNIFORM PHI DISTRIBUTION'. SET COORDINATES FOR NEW PARTICLE OR RESET DIRECTION COSINES OF OLD ONE. GENERATE RANDOM AZIMUTH SELECTION AND REPLACE THE DIRECTION COSINES WITH THEIR NEW VALUES.
        Parameters:
        IENTRY - IENTRY
        LVL - LVL

      • ANNIH_AT_REST

        protected static void ANNIH_AT_REST()
        Called by ELECTR. Handle annihilation at rest.

      • sample_double_compton

        protected static void sample_double_compton(double wo,
                                            int ie)
        Called by COMPT. Samples a double Compton scattering event and puts the resulting particles (2 photons and 1 electron) on the stack. wo is the incident photon energy in units of the electron rest energy; ie is the energy index that was needed and determined in COMPT in order to decide if single or double Compton scattering is to be simulated.
        Parameters:
        wo - wo
        ie - ie

      • sample_triplet

        protected static void sample_triplet()
        Called by PAIR. Handle triple production. The treatment is based on Borsellino's first Born approximation result (see Eq. 4B-3002 in the pair article of Motz, Olsen and Koch). As the kinematic of the process is already complicated enough and the cross section itself is not simple either, a Markov-chain method is used to sample triplet events from the Borsellino equation without any additional approximations (other then the use of the first Born approximation and the assumption of free electrons implied by Borsellino's derivation).

      • reset

        public static void reset()
        Reset global variables for re-use.
